title: Joe Biden: The veep takes his pre-campaign to Clinton?s turf
content:
Joe Biden ’ s jumping right into Hillary Clinton ’ s sandbox — and New York Democrats are eager to see him play .
Biden ’ s Thursday swing through New York , home of the Clinton campaign headquarters and the state she once represented , is perhaps the most aggressive stop of the coy pre-campaign he ’ s running .
He starts the day talking about women ’ s issues with a rape kit backlog event ( where he ’ ll appear with Attorney General Loretta Lynch , whose Justice Department is probing Clinton ’ s email server use ) , then use an appearance with Stephen Colbert to showcase his unscripted style , something many see as his strongest asset in a potential challenge to Clinton .
Between , he ’ ll hit her where it really hurts — her standing with liberal Democrats . Joined by New York Gov . Andrew Cuomo , as eager a Clinton supporter as there is among elected officials , Biden will headline an event to support a new $ 15 minimum wage for fast-food workers , a major cause among progressives .
The vice president ’ s office insists these are all official events , and that they ’ d be doing them regardless of his exploration of a presidential run .
But fewer and fewer people see this as anything but the rumblings of a Biden campaign — much to the excitement of many of her old constituents .
“ If anyone can present a strong , robust and lasting challenge to Hillary Clinton , it ’ s the vice president , ” said Rep. Hakeem Jeffries , a Brooklyn Democrat who said he ’ s leaning toward endorsing the front-runner but first wants to see whether Biden will run .
Neal Kwatra , a New York-based consultant with deep ties to labor and progressives throughout the city , said Biden ’ s long history with labor could make a difference for voters in a city with the highest union membership in the state . Plus , progressives are feeling flushed again about President Barack Obama , and that would help Biden .
“ If he ’ s going to be making the case for a third Obama term , he ’ s got a lot of stuff that can be appealing to progressives , ” Kwatra said .
Many of the highest-profile New York Democrats have already endorsed Clinton , including Cuomo , Sens . Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand , state Attorney General Eric Schneiderman and state Comptroller Tom DiNapoli .
But in the roiling world of New York politics , where nearly every race is determined in Democratic primaries and where nearly every politician brims with a self-importance that makes them believe their support matters as much as that of any major national figure , the backing of traditional power brokers only counts for so much .
New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio ’ s still holding out , putting his relationship with the Clintons and other major Democratic forces on the line in the hopes of using the progressive seal of approval he ’ s asserted to turn himself into more of a national figure . His spokesperson said he wasn ’ t available for comment about Biden and Clinton and progressives .
Gustavo Rivera , a state senator who represents the Bronx and consider himself progressive , said he wouldn ’ t use that term to describe Clinton—though he has endorsed her .
“ Do I agree with her on every position ? No , ” Rivera said . But he added , “ When you take her as a whole candidate , I think she is an incredibly strong candidate . ”
That said , Rivera acknowledged that he ’ s one of the people backing Clinton who wants Biden to get in . He ’ d force her to pay more attention to the issues they care about , and drive her further to the left than Sen. Bernie Sanders ( I-Vt. ) has so far .
Clinton ’ s campaign declined comment on Biden coming to town , or her standing with New York progressives .
And there ’ s no chance of a Clinton run-in : she 'll be in Columbus , Ohio and Milwaukee on Thursday , campaigning and raising money .
Meanwhile , Biden will expand on the economic fairness message he started testing Monday in Pittsburgh , standing in front of a union crowd and attacking “ trust fund babies , ” and coming close to John Edwards ’ 2008 “ two Americas ” line .
“ The tax code ’ s not fair . It ’ s simply not fair , ” Biden said then . “ There used to be one America . ”
Dan Morris , a consultant for New York groups involved with the Fight for 15 and other progressive causes , said Biden ’ s record to date isn ’ t reassuring . He ’ s only been for a $ 12 federal minimum wage , the anti-crime legislation he wrote in the 1990s has disproportionately hit African-Americans , and there ’ s little evidence that he ’ d resonate with black , Latino and female voters who ’ d benefit most from raising the minimum wage , among other core progressive causes .
But Morris said a Biden campaign would be a good thing for Democrats ; it would force Clinton to grapple with many progressive issues that she hasn ’ t before , and it would lower the threshold for victory , making Sanders more of a factor .
“ A Biden candidacy is both an opportunity and an obstacle for Clinton , ” Morris said .
As for Biden ’ s trying to make himself the progressive in the 2016 race , Morris isn ’ t convinced .
“ He ’ s more of a question mark , ” Morris said , “ than an exclamation point . ”
content_original:
Joe Biden’s jumping right into Hillary Clinton’s sandbox — and New York Democrats are eager to see him play.

Biden’s Thursday swing through New York, home of the Clinton campaign headquarters and the state she once represented, is perhaps the most aggressive stop of the coy pre-campaign he’s running.

Story Continued Below

He starts the day talking about women’s issues with a rape kit backlog event (where he’ll appear with Attorney General Loretta Lynch, whose Justice Department is probing Clinton’s email server use), then use an appearance with Stephen Colbert to showcase his unscripted style, something many see as his strongest asset in a potential challenge to Clinton.

Between, he’ll hit her where it really hurts — her standing with liberal Democrats. Joined by New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, as eager a Clinton supporter as there is among elected officials, Biden will headline an event to support a new $15 minimum wage for fast-food workers, a major cause among progressives.

The vice president’s office insists these are all official events, and that they’d be doing them regardless of his exploration of a presidential run.

But fewer and fewer people see this as anything but the rumblings of a Biden campaign — much to the excitement of many of her old constituents.

He might even put some of them in contention.

“If anyone can present a strong, robust and lasting challenge to Hillary Clinton, it’s the vice president,” said Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, a Brooklyn Democrat who said he’s leaning toward endorsing the front-runner but first wants to see whether Biden will run.

And Jeffries is not alone.

Neal Kwatra, a New York-based consultant with deep ties to labor and progressives throughout the city, said Biden’s long history with labor could make a difference for voters in a city with the highest union membership in the state. Plus, progressives are feeling flushed again about President Barack Obama, and that would help Biden.

“If he’s going to be making the case for a third Obama term, he’s got a lot of stuff that can be appealing to progressives,” Kwatra said.

Many of the highest-profile New York Democrats have already endorsed Clinton, including Cuomo, Sens. Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand, state Attorney General Eric Schneiderman and state Comptroller Tom DiNapoli.

But in the roiling world of New York politics, where nearly every race is determined in Democratic primaries and where nearly every politician brims with a self-importance that makes them believe their support matters as much as that of any major national figure, the backing of traditional power brokers only counts for so much.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio’s still holding out, putting his relationship with the Clintons and other major Democratic forces on the line in the hopes of using the progressive seal of approval he’s asserted to turn himself into more of a national figure. His spokesperson said he wasn’t available for comment about Biden and Clinton and progressives.

Gustavo Rivera, a state senator who represents the Bronx and consider himself progressive, said he wouldn’t use that term to describe Clinton—though he has endorsed her.

“Do I agree with her on every position? No,” Rivera said. But he added, “When you take her as a whole candidate, I think she is an incredibly strong candidate.”

That said, Rivera acknowledged that he’s one of the people backing Clinton who wants Biden to get in. He’d force her to pay more attention to the issues they care about, and drive her further to the left than Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has so far.

Clinton’s campaign declined comment on Biden coming to town, or her standing with New York progressives.





And there’s no chance of a Clinton run-in: she'll be in Columbus, Ohio and Milwaukee on Thursday, campaigning and raising money.

Meanwhile, Biden will expand on the economic fairness message he started testing Monday in Pittsburgh, standing in front of a union crowd and attacking “trust fund babies,” and coming close to John Edwards’ 2008 “two Americas” line.

“The tax code’s not fair. It’s simply not fair,” Biden said then. “There used to be one America.”

Dan Morris, a consultant for New York groups involved with the Fight for 15 and other progressive causes, said Biden’s record to date isn’t reassuring. He’s only been for a $12 federal minimum wage, the anti-crime legislation he wrote in the 1990s has disproportionately hit African-Americans, and there’s little evidence that he’d resonate with black, Latino and female voters who’d benefit most from raising the minimum wage, among other core progressive causes.

But Morris said a Biden campaign would be a good thing for Democrats; it would force Clinton to grapple with many progressive issues that she hasn’t before, and it would lower the threshold for victory, making Sanders more of a factor.





“A Biden candidacy is both an opportunity and an obstacle for Clinton,” Morris said.

As for Biden’s trying to make himself the progressive in the 2016 race, Morris isn’t convinced.

“He’s more of a question mark,” Morris said, “than an exclamation point.”
